ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara Brock
Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Teaching fellow seemed rather uninterested in the course and did not seem to participate in discussion.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  im not sure.

Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara is extremely knowledgable and makes great points in discussion. I felt very comfortable asking her for advice. While I know she's busy with her own work, I would have liked her to reach out more and be a little more hands on with students given that Karen was super busy this semester and there weren't that many students in the class.
Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  great comments on my papers! And whenever you jumped in during discussions, Samara, you moved things along in a really great and new direction!

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Excellent course. This type of course should be one of the Foundations courses for FES.
This class has fascinating readings that I loved reading and discussing but was very challenging and had a large workload, especially for students with no anthropology background.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Very interesting and well chosen syllabus
Discussion.
The readings.
The readings were very interesting--I was pleased with the choices!
The reading were very interesting and some of them were very different which was great. It gave a wide array of perspectives on environmental knowledge and environmental issues as a whole.

The readings were generally engaging and thought-provoking. It was also nice that most of the readings had been written recently, so that we as a class could get a good introduction to the current state of scholarship in this area.

The reading list and the other students in the course. I was so inspired by my classmates and extremely impressed by their thoughtful comments. Discussion was awesome. I really enjoyed the reading list: it covered a wide variety of topics and had a little for everyone, and it exposed me to some really interesting environmental debates and topics that I don't get elsewhere at FES (indigenous rights, mining company activities, debates about "expertise").
I loved the discussion format of the class!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: We should have spent less time deciphering the intent of the author, and more time talking about how we can take these readings and theories and apply them to our own work.
The class size was a little bit large for a discussion-based class.

While I enjoyed having different students run class each week, I would have liked to see Samara and Karen step up more and keep the discussion more on track. I'm new to anthro and this style of class discussion, so this may be normal, but I felt like the debate meandered way too much and I would have liked more structure to discussion. Or at least varying the style.

I think the papers were of an awkward length - a little too long for a reflection paper. I now your courses in the past had weekly 1 page papers or something? A difficult balance to strike, I think I would have liked to write perhaps 5 papers of 4-6 pages on 5 weeks of my choice, so I could choose which readings spoke to me most. Connecting the different readings came very naturally, though sometimes the limitation of connecting the readings just within the "block" of readings that the papers were about was a little restricting. A note on the discussion format: As I'm sure you are also aware, there were some people who rarely spoke up during discussions. I don't know if there is anything you could have done about that. If it's because they were uncomfortable with the discussion format, maybe clarify even more at the introductory class what the format will look like. I liked that in the last few classes we had some situations of just going around the room to hear everyone's comments individually, which I think worked well, and could have been put to great use every now and then throughout the course.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I was hoping there would some explanations of basic anthropological theories even though I understand the course is more like a upper level seminar with intensive discussion. On the other hand I do think the concepts were explained well when students asked questions based on the readings. Maybe I am just used to a bit more lecture in the beginning.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I need more social science classes in my program.

Understanding the tensions between local knowledge of communities, and scientific knowledge of (in my case) international NGOs with "technical expertise" has already been super hepful in my internship right now (and I've only been here 1 week), and I know it will be extremely helpful going forward too. It was also a great class to reflect critically on how we (personally and as a society) are biased in our knowledge preferences.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in anthropology and its role in environmental issues, especially in this concept of environmental knowledge and politics.
I wanted to get more experience in reading, discussing, and writing in the social science/anthro field and this class was awesome for that.
I knew I liked the weekly-book-then-discussion format, and I wanted to know more about the interface between communities and internationally operating institutions (businesses, governments, NGOs)

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I would say so, I think a lot of the materials will sink in more once I get back to the work life and will be working on environmental issues in the field and interacting with people from diverse backgrounds.
Yes! Exceeded them!
Yes, they exceeded my expectations!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I really enjoyed working with a partner for the discussion leading, I think it was very helpful to discuss the reading with a peer before discussing it with the class as a whole.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Highly recommended

Unfortunately, this class will not be offered again since the instructor is leaving. It's a real loss to F&ES that this happened. I am afraid that students will miss out on this wonderful class (and Professor Hbert's excellent mentorship) because of poor faculty leadership at F&ES. It's hard to take the school's commitment to interdisciplinary research and training seriously when they keep cutting social science faculty and marginalizing women in adjunct teaching roles or through failed promotions (even when they are promoted elsewhere among colleagues in their own discipline). Let us hope this changes in the future...

Unfortunately FES made a poor choice and let Karen go so this class won't be offered again in all likelihood. If it was though, students should definitely take it! FES needs more classes that encourage students to debate and challenge the status quo of environmental discourses, and especially more courses in the anthropology/qualitative- this was a great one for that.
